Why might antivirus software like Avast and Kaspersky flag Verus software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP"?

Antivirus software might flag Verus software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP" (Potential Unwanted Program) because it includes mining software, which could potentially be used by third parties to exploit your PC for mining purposes. This is a false positive warning, and you can learn more about it from resources like Malwarebytes and Kaspersky's blogs.

Avast and Kaspersky may flag the software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP". These are warnings that you are installing mining software, which may be installed by a third party to exploit your PC.
To find out more about the false positives, review the following resources:
https://blog.malwarebytes.com/detections/pup-optional-bitcoinminer/
https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/not-a-virus/18015/

What are some notable changes in the latest release of Verus?

Some notable changes in this release of Verus include alleviating peer banning behavior, staking enhancements, and activation support for VerusID. Additionally, there have been relative adjustments to the CPU and FPGA-equalizing VerusHash 2.1 Algorithm.

What is VerusID, and how does it differ from other blockchain ID implementations?

VerusID is a fully functional blockchain protocol, not just an ID system. Unlike most blockchain ID implementations, there is no corporation involved in the protocol. VerusIDs provide opportunities for identity applications and offer features such as quantum-ready friendly crypto addresses, full decentralization, revocability, recoverability, and privacy.
